title: Beep, beep: Anacacia set to deliver courier investment
text:
Buyout firm Anacacia Capital has been in discussions to drive away with a substantial stake in transport and logistics company Direct Couriers.

Street Talk understands Anacacia boss Jeremy Samuel and his team have held talks to invest in the courier services business, in a deal that would see them emerge as the company’s biggest shareholder.

The mooted deal comes only weeks after Anacacia's Jeremy Samuel signed a deal to acquire Root Partnership, an independent consulting and project management firm with about 100 staff. Jessica Hromas.

Direct Couriers offers courier and taxi truck services for local same day delivery and interstate and international delivery services, operating in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Perth, Adelaide and Auckland.

The company was started by Barry Reichman, who is still Direct Couriers’ managing director, in the early 1990s to service Sydney’s advertising agencies, television stations and post production companies.

It expanded in Melbourne and beyond, and its business has broadened to engage about 850 courier sub-contractor drivers and offer warehousing facilities at its branches. It has more than 170 staff.
description: Buyout firm Anacacia Capital has been in discussions to grab a big stake in Direct Courier.
